reviews.author: Bonnie

reviews.title: "Good things come in smaller packages"
reviews.text:
When unboxing the standard Google Home, I was immediately surprised at how the device was much smaller than expected, but in such a good way. I'm not particularly a fan of having super tall cylinders as smart speakers around the house, and this is the perfect size. Combine the size with Google's smooth, matte plastic and home-friendly fabric, and the Google Home is a striking little companion. The Google Home app on my iPhone made the setup of this thing really fast and really simple.

The Google Home, while not the smallest of the Google smart speaker family, might just be the most home friendly, and that's due largely to its design. This device has a really unique shape that makes it look like it belongs in the home. For me, it's a really great computer desk companion. I can bluetooth my computer audio to it, ask Google assistant questions, or play music while I work. The speaker quality in the Google Home is what I'd call “fine.” It's not super “bassy,” but it's fairly good quality if you're not blasting the volume. I think this is more of a “background music” player as opposed to the center piece of your home audio. That said, everything about the Google Assistant component works as expected, and it's a good price point. Recommended as a gift or a new addition to your own smart home.
reviews.author: Vingole

reviews.title: "A great way to start your smart home improvements."
reviews.text:
Google Home : 

The Google Home is a nice way to get started in the smart home movement, for people who aren't tech savy. It does pretty much what you'd expect; it answers your questions, controls your devices, and the sound quality is good enough for listening to music. I also have an Amazon echo, and the Google Home sound quality is better; it seems richer with deeper bass response. Also, I like the fact that it recognizes different voices, and tailors its responses depending upon whom is asking it questions.

Installation was a little confusing at first, but once you start is relatively easy to follow. The steps are as follows:
1. Plug in your Google Home
2. Download the Google Home app on your smartphone
3. Sign in with your google account. (You need to have already created a google account to use google home).
4. Tap the setup icon on your google home, top right corner
5. Watch the tutorial!!!
6. Follow the directions.

Once you have it all configured, its a neat machine, I can control the GE smart light that came with the bundle, turning it on and off with just a command. So far the most useful task it can do is setting up timers and alarms. When I am cooking, I can tell it to set a timer for 30 minutes, and it sounds an audible alarm when the time is up. Haven't burned a pizza since I got it.
reviews.author: Storyteller

reviews.title: "Great Product to build your smart home around!"
reviews.text: Fun item to have in the house. I have the home and now a couple of mini's too. All are in different rooms so no matter where I am I can ask them to do something like turn on or off or dim a light. Adjust the thermostat. Tell me the weather, time, traffic, info on just about anything I need, play music I want in 1 room or as a group in all rooms ( was a nice feature at Christmas having the whole house full of the same background Christmas music in every room at a nice comfortable volume instead of 1 location blasting the sound to all my guests). My wife and I use it to help with getting things done and remembering things by saying Hey Google add such & such to my shopping list, to do list, follow up on list, etc. Comes in very handy when you think of something out of the blue and can just tell your assistant to add it to your list or ask Google what is on your list and even pull up the list when you are out or at the store with your smart phone. Add smart bulbs, smart locks, thermostat, smart plugs, etc and you can control just about anything you want by speaking it or pulling it up on your phone app. Way too many things to list here and with technology going the way it is smart home equipment will be expanding and covering more things than I can imagine. We enjoy it very much and will continue to add to and build our system even more.
reviews.author: Jack

reviews.title: "Very helpful in many ways"
reviews.text: First let me start by saying that I received this product free to give my personal review on it. It was in no way influenced by anyone. Let me start by saying that my husband and I are not up to date on the today's technology. In fact, I was very afraid to try and set this up when we first received it because I didn't want to break it or mess it up to where I couldn't give you my opinion on this device. We actually had our daughter come just in case we started to over think the process. She was very knowledgeable and helpful in the installation. We also found that you can go on YouTube and find videos on how to set this up from start to finish. It turned out to be very simple - only took a few minutes and it was done. I never thought we would use this product a lot hence the reason we never purchased one of our own. But it has really turned out to be a very helpful device to us. I love knowing about weather and rely on this everyday to find out all I can. The second most favorite feature has to be the music. I'm home a lot during the day by myself as my husband works and being able to play music through this has really sped up my day's while he's gone. We are excited to learn everything this little device can do and how much more it can help us on a day to day basis. We highly recommend this to anyone interested in adding more technology to their homes.
reviews.author: Tweedygirl

reviews.title: "A really neat smart speaker with great sound"
reviews.text:
This is one of Google's “Home” smart speaker/assistants. It has a good speaker for its size, though not as good as the larger Google “Home Max Chalk” but better than the Google “Home Mini Chalk”. Like all of Google's smart home devices, this smart speaker is a lot of fun, seriously ‘cool', and so easy to setup. BTW: Google's “Home”, “Home Max” and “Home Mini” smart speakers install and work exactly the same way so if you also come across my review of them, you may notice considerable similarity. 
So long as you have a nearby power outlet, a Google login, a smartphone to load the “Google Home” app, and a home wireless router within range, the voice activated Google “Home”speaker/personal assistant will be a breeze to install and use. Once it is setup, it's “Look ma, no hands”. All I had to say was “Hey Google” and fire-off a question or command. I even ‘paired' it with my iPhone so not only can I listen to internet-based music (ie. Pandora, YouTube, Spotify, etc.), but I can also listen to any music stored on my iPhone through the speaker of the Google “Home”, and the “Home Max”. Still, I'm glad these devices include touch as well as voice controls for start/stop, volume, and mic mute so I don't have to interrupt the music with a “Hey Google” just to pause it or adjust the volume. I also like broadcasting my voice messages throughout the house wherever a Google Home smart speaker exists.
reviews.author: Jeff

reviews.title: "Google Home"
reviews.text:
This is but one of the many devices Google offers as a "Home Assistant" and I must say I am impressed with their products. It is in my opinion, superior to the competition. The voice commands work near perfection. I have a "low quality" voice on other devices and applications so I was doubtful this device would be any different. I am pleasantly surprised with the results so far. Setup is easy and quick (you must have a smartphone or tablet to do this). The assistant is always "learning" your requests. For example as a test I ask what the market price of gold is today. The assistant at first could not answer this and is now sending links to my phone (via the Google Home app). I would expect in the near future it will learn this task. It does things like phone number lookup, ordering pizza, weather, etc.quickly and without fail. 
The device also streams music with good fidelity and can be quite loud if needed. It links with other Google devices easily and flawlessly; however it does not appear that it can be a satellite speaker for other Google devices. Again, make sure you have a smartphone or tablet to set this device up and to control it at times. Also, I live in a rural area with DSL that goes out frequently and can be lower bandwidth and at times this can result in interruptions of device functions (not the device's fault). I really like these products and I highly, highly recommend them.
reviews.author: DaveWayOutWest

reviews.title: "Cool little device"
reviews.text:
We recieved a google home mini, google home, a google home max, chromecast, smart light bulb and router all in the same day. Having an updated smart home has been a fun adventure offering some unexpected conveniences. 

The only difference , I believe, between the speakers, is sound quality. But it is a big difference. They all sound pretty good. We listen to a lot of music, audiobooks, and podcasts. We enjoy having a speaker to listen to them. 

Our 8 year old loves asking the google home to play his favorite songs while he cleans his room or plays with legos. As he was playing legos, he asked it to play the Lego soundtrack and then asked it to play the Lego movie,. He was thrilled to be able to accomplish these tasks without having to ask his older sisters or myself to help him.

 The speakers are very convenient to ask simple questions, or find out the weather. Simple, lazy things like that. We also just discovered it acts like a intercom system with all the other devices. This feature is very convenient in our 3000 SF home - decreasing the amount of yelling required to communicate with all four of our children. 

We also appreciate that calls can be made through the google home speakers. This is especially convenient because we do not have a land line and not all of our kids have cell phones. 

The google home has a great sound. It's a little more bass-y sounding than the mini making it perfect for our living room, get togethers, etc.. All in all a pretty fun device that eliminates the need for other speakers.
reviews.author: Levi

reviews.title: "Google Home, Not Your Grandfather's Radio"
reviews.text:
OK, you're considering a dive into home automation. The question, where to start. You can get intelligent lightbulbs, switches, outlets, thermostats, and TVs. Your ability to use these devices is limited to how you can interact with them. If you want to use the Google Home infrastructure, the first interface is going to be your Android or iOS device. While this works, it is somewhat cumbersome (I've been doing it that way for a year).

Enter Google Home. Essentially, Home adds two addition features - the ability to speak commands and to listen to results without having to fumble for your cellphone or tablet. As a byproduct, it also adds decent audio to listen to streaming sources on the Internet and a "coolness" factor. It also has a limitation your cellphone or tablet doesn't have - Google Home has no display. As a result instead of viewing your options on your cellphone, you need to know what's available e.g. know that I have a light named front door that can be turned on/off (pretty easy) or the name and availability of a video stream I want to watch (maybe not too bad for a movie but might be harder for a TV episode I rarely watch).

Having said all that, there are times and features that really make voice control of your environment fantastic. While I can't say I couldn't live without it, it CAN BE very convenient.

By the way, in case you're interested, the time to install (with a pre-existing wifi network) from removing the plastic wrapper to my first command ("Hey Google, play some jazz.") was 8.5 minutes. Not bad for a new install!
reviews.author: drJ

reviews.title: "Great little smart speaker"
reviews.text: A great little gadget. The Home was neatly packaged and right out of the box I was up and running in just a few minutes. First you have to download the app on your phone or IPad and then follow a few steps to set it up. I already have a home mini and a home max setup in the house. They connect up with each other and I will be able to control various things from anywhere in the house. Currently I only have a few lights setup on the system but I plan to expand my options soon. I can control the lights from anywhere in the house. All you have to say is "Hey Google" and it is at your command. "Hey Google, turn off the lights in the living room" and they go out. Or Hey Google play some music in the den. Hey google lower the volume. "How cold is it outside" Or ask it anything about sports or what time does Home Depot open. It knows. One thing I have noticed is that when you ask Google a question, the answer is almost instantaneous. Another thing it is a great little speaker and the sound is great. It seems to fill the room with music when you ask it to play a song or play your favorite radio station. The Home is a relatively attractive device. It can fit pretty much any decor without drawing unwanted attention to itself. I have mine setup up in the bedroom on my nightstand and it is barely noticeable. The microphone is very sensitive and you can access it from anywhere in the room. You don't have to repeat yourself. If you are playing music the volume will go down so you can hear the response. Overall, I think I have a long way to go when it comes to tapping its full potential but I think it is a great starting point. The Home is definitely the way to go.
reviews.author: DixieLee25

reviews.title: "Very good sound quality"
reviews.text:
I have used this to control my GE smart bulbs, ChromeCast television, Nest thermostat and one google smart plug. It connects and works flawlessly with them all. Even if you are not sure if you want a “smart home” yet, this Google Home makes a very nice stand alone speaker for streaming music from Google, Youtube, Pandora, Spotify, etc.
You can always add smart products to your home later and connect them to Google Home.
The sound is definitely quite surprising coming from such a small device. Although it lacks the mega bass and extreme volume presence of its big brother, Google Home Max, it certainly can keep the music loud enough (or quiet enough) for all occasions. I also have a google home mini which has very nice speaker quality as well. However, if you want high quality sound, but you are not prepared to pay up for the Home Max, I would recommend you spend the extra to step up to this model from the mini if you are planning on using it to stream music. While this and the home mini do the identical thing, the speakers in this Google Home are definitely, in my opinion, worth the extra investment.
As with all the google home products, setup is a breeze. Simply plug it to any standard wall outlet and then open the google home app on your device. The app will automatically detect your google home and ask for WiFi password and that's about it. 
One thing which really stands out to me is how well these google home devices can hear and interpret what I say. Even my kids who speak very fast and not always so clearly are heard word for word by Google Home! Even if the music is turned way up it can detect your voice at nearly a whisper. And not just hear your voice but hear exactly what you say or ask. It is truly amazing!
reviews.author: Jake

reviews.title: "Home Sweet Home"
reviews.text: How often are we as adults told that we need to settle? For me, it started at five years old with a painstakingly constructed and extensive Christmas List which made my parents laugh, pat me on the head, and subsequently present me solely with the first item. Similarly, in the adult world, viewers never tire of the premise on "The Property Brothers" where the couple wants to purchase a waterfront home with a pool and a carriage house and ultimately settles for a beautifully remodeled spread overlooking a swamp with a hot tub and a finished basement. And I don't even have to tell you that, much like my childhood friends, I thought I would marry someone who resembled a young George Michael, but ended up instead with a partner who looks more like George Costanza (sorry baby, you know I love you). This familiar concept is what makes Google Home, a smart speaker with a whole lot more, so appealing: it perfectly caters to the fantastical aspirational side of us because you simply do not have to settle! The laundry list of things that it can do is pretty great: play music from different apps and playlists, as well as randomly, provide you with the weather forecast and time, assist with Google searches, set alarms, tell jokes, even engage in trivia and Mad Libs(!), I have been told. For a much more entertaining list than the one I have provided, please refer to the latest Google Home commercial starring Macaulay Culkin, which will most certainly make you smile. Other than the fact that my mother-in-law insists on placing Google Home in the bathroom, since she is convinced it is the air freshener (another reviewer also mentioned it resembles this), I must say that this product is truly incredible and a welcome addition to our home!
reviews.author: Renovator

reviews.title: "How did I ever function without this?!"
reviews.text:
Decided to venture into the world of Google Home & so happy I did! I used to use my "Ok Google" function randomly on my cell phone; mainly while driving, for a hands-free experience.. Never thought of using it at home for random information..But, with this amazing Google Home, I find myself using it all the time! It's great from early morning (when I'm getting ready for work, getting dressed, & need to know the traffic situation that day or the weather or sports & news.) Oh, of course, listening to music is what I use most! It connects smoothly to my favorite music streaming apps & all I have to do is say, "Hey Google, play (this song, band, etc.)" Google Home also works perfectly connected to my Google connected services on my cell phone, such as my calendar, for example, if I need to know my schedule the next day or info on special events coming up. It really is like having my own personal assistant..a very 'worldly & brilliant' assistant, that could literally answer any question I could think of! Even tell me a joke if I needed a corny laugh lol. 
 Setting up the Google Home couldn't have been any easier! I usually look up a video online for easy installation, but I didn't even need it.. Out of the box, it comes with a card with a couple steps to set up (the wire-power connection, download the Google Home app (on your mobile device)..& the rest is beyond simple & quick..Thru the app, the connections & start up are all done automatically, with minimal input. I was so impressed at how quickly it was set up & ready to go! I love the sleek design & compactness; not much bigger than a soda can but twice as wide...& I know it might sound weird but I absolutely love the little dot lights that light on the slanted top! They light up in different colors, & spiral sometimes, for different commands, questions or purposes. To me, this looks so 'futuristic' & looks perfect with the rest of my bedroom decor! 
 I got this, along with a couple other Google Home connected devices, that I'll review separately.. But just a heads-up~ Everything in the Google Home line connects as easily as this was, to set up. I'm telling you, this Google Home will open your eyes to a whole new world!
reviews.author: Tommy305

reviews.title: "This is the Middle Child of the Google Home Line"
reviews.text:
I am perplexed as to the current viability of the Google Home smart speaker. Since it's inception Google has added the Home Mini (much less expensive), the Home Max and now the Home Hub with a digital display (costing just slightly more than the Home speaker. It seems that this middle child has been squeezed out of the family.

Here are my observations and experience. 

PROS: The Google Home speaker with Google Assistant will capably answer any question you can think and responds with great sound quality. Like all of the previously mentioned Google devices you can make phone calls, control smart home devices, get recipes and self-help info, control your TV, etc. Fairly capable audio with it's 2 inch driver and two internal passive radiators, 

APPEARANCE / FEATURES: It looks like and air freshener. It does have a clean look and does not look overbearing in my den. The flat, slightly inclined top surface is a touch panel where you can change the volume, play and pause the music or activate the Google Home assistant with a tap. I like the four multi-colored lights that race in a circle to indicate that the device is responding - easy to see across the room. The physical button to mute the speaker (suspend listening) and avoid inadvertent responses is a great feature as well. Excellent device for streaming music services (i.e. Google Play, YouTube, Spotify, Pandora, etc.). The Home is also bilingual to accommodate two languages such as English and Spanish at the same time and recognize commands in both languages interchangeably. "Continued Conversation" and Multiple Actions" enhancements have been added to improve user experience. Hands-free calling and Bluetooth allows import of contacts from your phone to make calls. Home also uses Bluetooth to sync up to other devices.

CONS: Google's middle offering smart speaker still cannot integrate with Google software features. No integration with Gmail to get insight on new e-mails. Same with Google Calendar - not able to create new events (although it can read out existing events in your Google Calendar), cannot make phone calls with Google Voice or jot down some quick notes in a Google Doc. No other color options out-of-the-box unless you add an aftermarket snap on base or cover. 

SUMMARY: The Google Home speaker is best suited for someone that wants decent sound quality without having to spend big bucks. Pairing a Google Mini and a Bluetooth speaker may be a better option. And the price seems to be falling - thus making it more attractive.
reviews.author: Rick

reviews.title: "Not too big, not too small, just right!"
reviews.text:
I received these items free of charge through the Lowes Loop program to review and report on.

Google Home/Mini/Max Smart Speakers

Initial Setup and Performance:

The Google Home was the last module received and was just as easy to set up. A quick check with the Google Home app found that the Home was waiting for connection. The controls integrated into the top are more versatile and responsive than those found in the Home Mini or Home Max, with the pause and volume functions on the top that worked well.

Voice commands on the Home worked well, although there was often some confusion between speakers in the kitchen and living room when I tried to get the Home to play music. If the Mini could hear me better, it would start playing music rather than the Home. I don't doubt that there's a setting that would remedy this, but I haven't found it yet.

Speaking of sound quality, the three speakers (Home, Home Mini and Home Max) were as expected, with the sound quality and maximum volume increasing with size. While none of them were a substitute for a proper hifi system, each was of adequate quality for background listening. The big boy, the Max was capable of respectable sound quality and volume in a smallish room like my office although it was no match for either the monitors attached to my computer (M-Audio Studiophile DX4) or my vintage 2-channel system with large English monitors. Most surprising though was the sound quality that came from the Home speaker, the mid sized one. I could hear actual bass coming from them and I was repeatedly and pleasantly surprised by the quality of the Pandora stream being played. This is the Mama Bear of the three, just right, not too big but big enough to please.

As I have an Amazon Echo Dot placed beside the kitchen Home Mini, I was able to evaluate the relative sound quality between them, as well as the effectiveness of their responses.

In terms of the sound quality, the Echo Dot has a fairly thin and tinny sound, befitting its low price. It's good for low background listening or spoken audio, such as news. The Home Mini has a much smoother sound, and although lacking in bass, makes those spoken audio or short audio clips much more listenable. However, if you're like my wife, you will play it loud without a care for the sound quality and anything, including her transistor radio, will do that.

As far as the quality of the responses to questions go, simple stuff like "how many milliliters in a quart" or "what's the nearest Italian restaurant" are pretty easy and accurate. But the AI response for most other things is pretty lacking. One advantage of the Echo is that it can notify you when your package has shipped or arrived and Google has yet to yield that information to me. Of course, you will be expected to ask it to tell you a joke, but Google, was it necessary to have the punch line end with a figurative rimshot? The noises at the end are just juvenile and Amazon doesn't use them.

Impressions and Conclusions:

Any of the Home speakers will interface with the Google system and the Home Mini is small and inconspicuous for placement around the house. The original Home is the Goldilocks/Mama Bear, just right. It takes up hardly more room on a table than the Mini but has a fully-baked sound quality. Which brings us to the Home Max. Yes, it's sound quality is even better, but at a cost of size. It has transitioned from a compact smart speaker to a large unit that occupies quite a lot of space, filling a bookshelf or other similar sized space. If you want your smart speaker to substitute for a full-fledged sound system, then this is your speaker. But perhaps a better choice would be a Google-compatible receiver and speakers that would outpace the Max in sound quality.
reviews.author: SteveMac

reviews.title: "Great addition to the home"
reviews.text:
Do I need it, would I even use it?
This device can be a valuable addition to your house. Just thinking of all the things that this little device can do and what it replaces. It is kinda of like combining a dictionary, encyclopedia, personal organizer, clock, timer, headline news, recipe book, traffic monitor, cell phone, etc, etc into a small 4” high round decorative device. 

This is probably one of the most versatile information tools you could add to your household. Literally you will have a world of information at your fingertips combined with the ability to automate your home. 

Unboxing: First props to google for not making me get a machete to open the box. Packaging is clean, not excessive and easy to open. In the box is the speaker, power cord and paperwork. 

Physical Setup
The device itself is a sleek, modern looking small cylinder that will easily fit into most room décor. Find a room location, plug it in and the physically setup is done. 

Software Setup
For this part you will need a smartphone and a Gmail account. From your phone download the google home app. Open the app and it will walk you through a sign in process and the google home setup. Google has done an excellent job of making this process easy and painless. Just answer a few questions and google will do the rest. At the end google will ask you to train your voice. This is important as google allows you to have multiple users, each identified by their voice. Each user will receive their own personal results to inquiries. For example, if you ask google how long to get to work, google will identify who is speaking and determine, based on traffic how long it will take that person to get from home to their work. A second person with a 2nd work address will get a different result. 

Its setup, now what
For the google home to know that you are talking to it, you get its attention by saying “Hey Google or Ok Google” followed by your inquiry. The device is really smart and will understand a question in multiple forms. For example, if checking today weather, you could ask OK google, what's the weather OR will it rain today OR do I need to take my umbrella and in all cases the google home will tell you todays weather. This is where the fun begins, just start asking any questions. 


Is it worth it, would I use it
If you have never seen it or used it, you might be thinking, why do I need this, is it a just a novelty item. It's not, imagine anything that you might search for on your computer or other sources can now be done verbally by just asking. Get answers about weather, traffic, stock prices, news, distance to the moon or calculations like how much is 15% of 15056. You can even get driving directions, order food, find your phone, make a call, control smart devices in your house, play music, set alarms or timers, find a recipe and much more. 

Phone integration
Along with asking general questions the Google Home integrates with your phone. You can ask thing like, Hey Google call mom” or “how to I get to Autozone” then google will answer and send the driving directions to your phone. This is also handy if you misplaced your phone, just ask where is my phone and google will call your phone. Note on making calls, Google looks to your contacts in Gmail when making a call. So if you have the name mom in your Gmail contacts along with her phone number, you can tell google to call mom. If, however, you are an iPhone user you will need to copy you contacts into google so that the Google Home will have access to the names and numbers. If the number is not in your google contacts you could just tell google the number to call. 

Smart home integration
There are an ever number of growing products that work with the Google Home. These products allow the Google Home to control appliance and devices in your house. Too many to list here but in general you could control your TV, lighting, thermostat and other smart devices in your home. This will give you the ability to say “Hey google, turn on the kitchen lights” as an example. 

Conclusion
The is an amazing and versatile device, from telling you jokes or readings ebooks to keeping your schedule or ordering food. Just when you might thing that you have discovered all this can do, google keeps adding functionality. For me this was a great addition to my home.
reviews.author: Tony

reviews.title: "Fun to use, Good sound"
reviews.text:
Google Home

Included:
Google Home unit
AC power adapter with a nice long cord.
Get Started Card
Card with suggestion on what to ask.
Product info Card

Needed 
WiFi network
Electrical outlet
Android or iOS device with Bluetooth enabled
Google Home app
A google account

The Home is powered by the Google Assistant. You can ask it question, set alarms and reminders, get news, traffic info, make calls to your contacts list, use it as an intercom with two or more Google Home units, play back music and connect to Bluetooth speakers by speaking commands to the Home unit.

The Home unit is a little shorter than a can of spray paint but about 4 inches in diameter. There are two microphone on the edges of the top. Tapping the top center pauses and resumes play of whatever is currently playing. Sliding a finger across the beveled top will give you a manual method for volume control. Of course you can always use your voice VOLUME UP/DOWN. When touching the white LED's indicate your volume level. There are 4 colored LED's which react to your voice to show you that it's thinking. I own an Amazon Alexa, and I've notice less hesitation on most commands than with the Google Home. I think (my opinion), that basically for most look up commands you are just doing a Google search....just like on a computer. Alexa has dedicated activities and I believe the faster response of Alexa is because of that. But the response is Ok with Google Home especially if you don't have anything to compare it to. Home also has much better sound.

Home features a power port on the bottom to provide power, and a microphone switch on the back that enables you to turn off active listening and a power status light. On the bottom, you can see a circular rubber mat to keep it still on your table.

Voice recognition very good. Good results were obtained from across the room or speaking gently 10 feet away, with only an occasional need to repeat commands.

“OK GOOGLE” or “HEY GOOGLE are the start commands. 

“OK GOOGLE SET A TEN MINUTE TIMER FOR PIZZA”.

You string commands together such as 

“HEY GOOGLE PLAY BRIDGE OVER TROUBLE WATERS ON SPOTIFY”

The Google Home can take control of several thousands external things. You can find brand/devices in the settings section of the app. Stream music through music apps like Pandora (free account), Spotify (paid account only), YouTube Music, iHeartRadio and more. It can send a request to pull up a YouTube video over to your Chromecast (another smart unit). 

The Home is also a smart home hub in that it can also integrate with smart devices like smart light bulbs, (I have Sengled bulbs and a Nest Thermostat and Outdoor camera). Tell Home about your devices, allow them to log into your external device account and boom your connected.

Connecting through the Google Home app, the app will teach you things about the Home, like how it works and resources that provide instant access to a wide variety of free audio content. Settings is your friend, spend a little time exploring what you can connect. 

You cannot connect by wire to an external speaker, but you can via Bluetooth. 

Google Home is a pretty capable audio device. Once your smart device is set up with the Home, it's simple to begin listening to music. Either give the speaker a shout for some tunes, being as specific or obscure as you'd like, or just hit the Cast button near the top to give your phone free reign to push its audio straight to the Home. Remember settings? You can select your primary music service, but if your tell it to look for a specific service it will.

It is cool that Home has the ability to both receive and send Google Cast signals, making it able to stream music from your phone and send video streams to any Google Cast-compatible connected devices.

While Home beats the heck out of Google Home Mini for sound, it is not a Hi-Fi sound. It does some bass and some mid tones sounds and they are good– but, if you're expecting Google Home to replace your Hi-Fi setup forget it. 

This unit is a nice main unit in a Home Google network. You can add Google Mini Home in other locations anywhere within range of your WiFi, outdoor shed, pool area (note NOT water proof), think intercom. 

Home is bilingual. In the settings, you can equip two languages such as English and Spanish at the same time and it'll recognize commands in both interchangeably. Again settings! 

In setting again, you can change voice gender of the Google Assistant and the nationality, American, English or Australian. 

Home can customize its responses for all of your family members based on who's talking. Each of your family members needs to download the Home app to a phone, then they will be able to train the Home to recognize their voices by repeating the wake words a couple of times. 

The Home supports six different accounts, and offers individualized responses to questions about calendars and traffic. The Home will also play personal playlists on request. The feature works well for the most part, as long as your family members don't sound similar. 

You can search for a recipe on your phone, or just ask for a meat loaf recipe, It'll walk you through the ingredients and step-by-step directions. The Home can wait until you tell it that you're ready for the next ingredient or step, and skip forward and back in the directions as you need. 
 
Is Google listening to me? How safe is my information? How do I weigh privacy against convenience?Good questions to ask, but Home probably won't have the answers to your worries. The Home only records what you say after you activate it with a tap, or with the wake words. You'll see the LEDs light up in so you'll know that it's listening. In the Home app, you can look over your search history and delete a specific query or clear the history entirely if you'd like. There's also a mute button that stops it from listening for its wake word at all.

This a a great unit for the cost. I would recommend it for casual music listening, answering questions, getting traffic reports and most things you might ask Google on a computer.

Disclosure I was provided this unit for evaluation by Lowes.
